title: Publications
subtitle: Research papers and academic publications
description: A collection of my research papers, conference proceedings, and other academic contributions to the field of artificial intelligence.

papers.title: Binarizing Physics-Inspired GNNs for Combinatorial Optimization
papers.authors: M. Krutský, G. Šír, V. Kungurtsev, G. Korpas
papers.description: Building on insights from fuzzy logic and binarized neural networks, we developed methods that significantly improve the performance of Physics-inspired graph neural networks (PI-GNNs) on dense combinatorial optimization problems. Our research found that PI-GNNs struggle with denser problems due to their dependency on phase transition during training. We resolved the issue by informing the network about the relaxation of the underlying binary problem, adjusting the activation function and the loss.

papers.title: Geometric Deep Learning for the Rubik's Cube Group
papers.venue: IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems
papers.description: A novel deep learning approach leverages the Rubik's Cube's inherent symmetries to solve it efficiently. By thoroughly analyzing the problem's group-theoretical properties, we developed a symmetry-invariant neural architecture with graph convolutional layers that significantly compresses the cube's vast state space. This new architecture demonstrates superior performance, enhanced generalization, and improved problem-solving abilities compared to previous state-of-the-art results.

papers.title: "Cause" is Mechanistic Narrative within Scientific Domains: An Ordinary Language Philosophical Critique of "Causal Machine Learning"
papers.authors: V. Kungurtsev, L. C. Moore, G. Šír, M. Krutský
papers.description: A philosophical critique of causal machine learning that applies Ordinary Language methodology to investigate the semantics of cause and effect reasoning. The work examines how causality manifests differently across scientific domains (physics/engineering, biology, social sciences) and argues that definitive causal claims require evidence aggregation across multiple domains, highlighting methodological challenges in harmonizing language games and emergence across scales.

papers.title: Interpretable Symmetry-Aware Deep Learning for Planning
papers.description: A contribution to the Geometric Deep Learning framework by studying symmetries in planning problems and implementing symmetry-invariant graph neural network for the Rubik's cube problem. The presented architecture outperforms previous state-of-the-art solutions in cost-to-goal regression experiments and exhibits high interpretability, with explanations based on intrinsic properties being preferable to standard explainer algorithms.

papers.title: Exploring Symmetries in Deep Learning
papers.description: A comprehensive exploration of neural architectures that explicitly exploit domain symmetries, including weight-sharing schemes, convolutions, Deep Sets, and graph neural networks. The work demonstrates that symmetry-aware architectures outperform conventional models on problems exhibiting various symmetries, from simple functions like XOR to complex tasks like combinatorial problems.
